BY s. S. SMITH, EDITOR AND PROPRIETOR.

For the Boston Recorder & Telegraph. GEN ERAL ASSOCIATION OF CONNECTICUT This body assembled at Stratford on Tues

 day the 18th II o'clock, A. M., and was or ganized by choosing Rev. Mir. Dove, of Thompson, M Moderator; and Rev. MT. Mer- 1 win of New Haven, Scribe. Various mat

 ters of business of davotion furnished dili-

 gent and highly profitable occupation of their

 time till Thursday night. The actual business of tine Connecticut Missionary Society, the Connecticut Branch of the American Education Society, was 1 transacted. The sermon before the General Association was preached Tuesday forenoon, by the Rev. Noah Smith from the text "Mur- nlur not among yourselves; no man can come near me except the father that sent me

 draw him." The preacher showed that this

 inability was altogether an unwillingness,

 and pressed the conscience of the sinner

 with the alarming strength of his opposition to Christ and holiness. In the evening sermon

 was delivered by Rev. s. Green of Boston on

 the encouragements to prayer. "And it shall come to pass before they call will answer

 & while they are yet speaking will hear" At 10 o'clock Wednesday Morning, sermon

 was preached before the Connecticut Mis-

 sionary Society, by Rev. Noah Porter. Immediately after which an able and anima- ted report of the doings of the Americanl Ed

 ucation Society was read by the Secretary, Rev. l.. Bacon, of New Haven, followed with spirited addresses by Rev. MT. Lindsley of Hartford. Rev. Dr.. Chefter ofAlbany, N. Y.

 Rev. MT. Merwin, New-Haven, Rev. S. Green of Boston, Mass. and Rev. Elias Cor

 nelius, Secretary ofthe American Education

 Society.

 Ats o'clock F. M. very large cencourse of people assembled, from considerable dis tance, when narrative of the state of religion within the bounds of the General Association of Connecticut was read, presenting on the l whole such view ofthe present state and fui-

 ture prospect of that portion of our Zion as 1 must greatly comfort and encourage every heart.

 This interest was increased by several yer

 bal statements made by gentlemen who were

 delegates from foreign bodies, and blest with

 special revivals ofrelgion. Statementsrela- to Litchfeld County were of peculiarly en-

 couraging character, it appeared that most of

 the churches in that county were signally fav Ored at the present time. An interesting oc- currence was mentioned: in one church there was an individual who had some years

 come to the Lords table. A Christian broth

 CT had for some time attempting to deal with him according 10 the rules of the gospel. The

 church held meeting for prayer mutual con-

 fession and conference, at which it was

 expected brethren would be present from other churches where God was pouring out

 his Spirit. At the commencement of the

 meeting the brother who was dealing with the

 offender met him on the door step, and in-

 stead of admonishing him began to make confession to him that his motives and feeling | in his course of dealing with him, had been

 unholy, and greatly deficient in Christian

 love. Said the offending brother in surprise, supposed you wished me to make cOnfes- sion to you as ought, instead of your making confession to me. The feelings of these two

 brethren on the steps was immediately com

 municated to the brethren within. It melted

 them into tears, and they fell upon their

 knees and gave Godthe thanks.

 Another occurrence in the same county was

 mentioned. A woman had serious conyer- sation one morning with her husband on the

 duty of family prayer. He took his Bible, and after bordering the passage containing the resolution of Joshua, ''as for me and my house we win serve the Lord ;'' he wrote it on leaf and subscribed his name. His wife

perIshed by fall who was so remarkable for the tenacity of his hold. e.

 The first witness examined was his Lord ships factOtum, Mir. H.

 A Juror. Do yOn recognize that body, Mir. H."

 MT. H. "Yes, Gentlemen, (bursting into tears) these are the remains of the defunct Chancellor"

 Juror; Can you give us any information how the departed Minister came .o his Pnd!'' Mr' H.: ''Alack, alack, that should have to tell the tale! he jumped out of his office window Onthe evening of the 18th of May" Juror: Had you observed any thing extra | ordinary in his nlanner-any symptoms of de- spondency or distress of mind." MT. H.: Not in particular, Gentlemen. My Lord was always in great distress about mo- ney. for he could not get as much as he wish I ed for. poor gentleman, and often talked of coming to want, but he was no worse in this way imm ediatelys before his demise than for merly."

 Juror: "Did he ever speak of resignins?'' MT. H.: {" Yes, he certainly did very ire quently: but Lord bless me. gentlemen, ] always thought hewas resigned to his office." l Juror: " How do you accoHnt then for his jumping out of the window. ! that when liberality came in at the door. it was time for orthodoxy to fly out of the win i dow sand as e1could never abide Mr. Can 1 ming, he had notion that if he in his wig robes, together with half dozen more, were seen jumping out of the window when Mir. Canning mounted the cadinet stairs, the neighbours would have supposed that the | Stadt-house was on ire-in short, that the l world was at an end-and that there would be rare alarm and cOnsternation in the country.

 Juror: "But did not he reckon on break ing his neck ?"

 Mr. H.: "NO sir; to tell you the truth, as 1 I'm in a manner bound to do, being upon oath, he intended to throw himself upon h,s majesty, ,and counted upon finding him as soft as d feather bed but Lord gentlemen he proved as firm as a rock, and as hard as oak, and my poor Lord was dashed to pieces, as you see.'' e

 The coroner; Gentlemen, think it unne- cessary to go further into his case. It is plain that the deceased destroyed himself, under the dcllsion that he was about to do wrong to others; and as his purpose was criminal, it should effect the act; you will therefore, do well :n returning verdict of felo de SC, and the remains shall he deposited with every circumstance of fignominy in the cross road"

 MT. H.: Gin great distress)" For Heavens sake Gentlemen, take care that there is no turnpike near the cross road. for the cry of two pence in the neighborhood would raise Fmy Lord from the grave"

 ] The next body viewed was that of MT. Peel. His head looked as if it had taken fire. The person formerly 80 fair was covered with lvid marks of modification. It was given in evidence that the defunct had an insuppor- table aversion to MT. Canning as Premier, as he suspected him of an intention to smug- gle the Pope into the country. On the day of the rash act he had been reading The Up l holsterer, and the following parts were blis- tered with tears, and underlined in pencil "Mr. Razor: I say Mr. Qnidnunc, can't sleep in my bed for thinking of the Protes- tants if the Papists should get the better"

 Quidnunc; I'll tell your--the geographer of our coffee-house was saying the other day. that there is huge tract of land about the pole. Note. in the unhappy gentleman's hand writing. We have sent Perry to find it out] where the Protestsnts may return, and that the Papist will never be able to beat them out, if the Northern powers hold together, and the Grand Turk makes diversion in their favor."

 "Razon: That makes me easy. I'm glad the Protestantswi know where to go if the Papist should get the better."

 The jury in order to prevent the forfeiture of the defunct's high character, were charita- ply induced to return verdict of Insanity. | The Duke of Wellington was next viewed. The hero who had triumphed in so many pitched battles. had perished, it appeared, by breaking his own head just by way of expe- (riment of his powers. Witnesses were called, who proved that his Grace had discovered great irritability on the appointment of MT. Canning, ana declared that he saw no reason why he should be content with being C@ssf alone, and that he would be also Cesar and the First Lord ofthe Treasury, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Duchy of Lancaster, Lord High Chancellor of England, apd his vice too, Master of the Rolls and ofthe Horse, and Master Extraordinary in the Chancery, aut nullus. On receiving Mr. Canning notes, and finding that it was not probahe that he could occupy all these stations, 40 resolved on falling, not like Roman, on bis sword but on his head. The melancholy catastrophe is known to all. An attempt was made to show that this brave soldier was terribly afraid ofthe Pope, and disordered in intellect by that ap- prehensiOn, n,-but the jury treated 1t with con- tempt and returned verdict of telo de SC. | The carcasses of Lords Westmoreland, Bathurst, and Melville. were then viewed. Land

 the jury were for rsturDing verdicts of suicide

 in fits of temporary insanity, hut were remnd-

 The annexed pOetical squib owes it's origin to Lord Melville, who said " For himselfhe declared distinctly, and on his honor. that from the hour of Lord LiverpooPs illness down to the hour of his resignation, he had not the slightest communication of any kind or description, with any of his colleagues re- garding the formation of new Administra- tion, and that there was of course no concert or conspiracy to resign.

 "When they do agree, their unanimity is wonderful" q SheridGn's Oritic."

 EXTRAORDINARY CONFLICT.

 Amongst other publications illustrative of country, asd the fearful chances of, our bor- der warfare, are articles published in the Ken lucky Gazette, etitled notes on Kentucky They are brief but interesting skethes giving the vivid details of scenes calculated to im- to which the early settlers of that, and other western states were exposed. The following are the details of one of the most extraordin- ary of these incidents :l-Alb. Argus.

 In the year f79l, Capt. William Hubbell, who had recently removed to Kentucky from Vermont, with his family, and after having fixed his family in the neighbourhood of Frankfort, then a frontier settlement, had re- turned to the eastward on business and was second time on his way to Kentucky; by the Ohio River. On the Monongahela, one of the branches Ofthe Ohio, he procured fiat boat, and embarked with Mir. Daniel Light, Mir. William Plascut, and his family consist ing of his wife and eight children destined for Limestone, (Kentucky.) On their progress down the river Ohio, ,and soon after passing Pittsburgh, they saw evident traces of Indian foes along the banks and there was evident reason that boat which they overlook, and which, through carelessness, was suffered to run aground on an island, had become prey to these merciless savages. Though Captain Hubbell and his party stopped for some time in the low part of the river, it did not arrlve, and it has never been by them heard of since. Before they reached the Mouth the Great Kenhawa they had by several successive ad- ditions, increased their number to twenty, consisting of men, women, & 8 children. The men, besides those already named, were John Stoner, an Irishman and Dutchman, (WhOse names are mot .recOlleCted) Messrs. Ray & Tucker and MT. Fitzpatrick, who had two daughters also on board. Informa- tion received at GaIliopolis confirmed the ex- pectatiOn, which appearances had previously raised, of serious conflict with large body of Indians; and, as Capt. Hubbell had been regularly appointed commander of the boat. every possible preparation for formidable and successful resistance to any expected attack was promptly made. The nine men were divided into three watch es for the night, which were alternately to continue awake and be on the look out for 2 hours at time.-The arms on board which consisted principally of old muskets much out of order, were collected, loaded and put in the best possible condition for service. At about sunset on the 2Sd of March l79l, this party overlook fleet of six boats in compa- ny, and intended to have continued with them, but as their passengers seemed more disposed to dancing than fighting, and soon after dark, notwithstanding the remonstranccs of Capt. Hubbell, they commenced fddling, and dancing and drinking, instead of prepar- ing their arms and taking the rest preparato- ry to battle-it was deemed more hazardous to be in such company than to be without them.-It was therefore determined, to pro- ceed rapidly forward by aid of the oars, and to leave those thoughtless fellows behind.- One of the boats, however, belonging to the fleet, commanded by Captain Greenhouse, pursued the same plan for short time, but at length all the crew fell asleep, and the boat ceased to be propelled by oars fell behind, whilst Capt. Hubbell and his party glided forward steadily alone. Early in the night a canoe was dimly seen floating bown the river

 in which it was supposed there were Indians accommodating and other indications of the neighbourhood and hostile intentions of a formidable and savage party of Indians mo- ticed.

 It was now agreed, that should an attack, as was probable,he deferred till morning, every man should be up before the dawn of day. in order to make as great a show as possible, of numbers and of strength and. that whenev- CT an action should take place, the women and children should lie down on the cabin floor, and be protected as we'll as they could, by trunks and other baggage placed around them. In this perilous situation they contin- ued during the night, and the captain, who had not slept more than an hour since he lett

 Pittsburgh, was too deeply impressed with the eminent danger which surrounded them to obtain rest at that time.

 Just as day light began to appear in the east and before the men were up and at their posts agreeably to arrangement, voice at some distance below them in plaintive tone. re. peatedly solicited them to come on shore, as theresMere some white men who wished te obtain U passage in their boat. This the cap tain very naturally and correctly concluded te | be an Indian artiRce, and its only effect wa: | to rouse the men and place every one on hi

coming in and observing the leaf, the text, and her husbands name, added her own shortly after his sister entering observed it, 'and:' :'ad- ded her name and the result was the three became nious, and that house became house of prayer.

 After these and several interesting ac- counts, some hundreds Ofthe children of God sat down together about the sacramental board, and commemOrated that wonderful d. tenement which procured them all their priv iliges and comforts, and laid the foundation for all these triumphs of divine truthSwhch are making glad the hearts of men and an gels.

 In the evening a powerful appeal was made by the Reverend Mir. Hewitt, expos ing the wide spread and horrible evils of intemperanee, and calling upon the minis ters of the most high God, by all their sO- lemn obligations and awful responsibilities to throw themselves in between the living and the dead.

 After which the Association passed u- nanimous resolve approving the object and principles of the" American Society for the promotion of Temperance"

 On Thursday forenoon, a sermon was preached and prayer-meetings were held of an hour each On the mornings of Wednesday and Thursday. All the meetings were well attended and discovered deep and solemn interest, and we cannot but hope blessing is left for the people and pastor of the place, who will not we trustb he soon forgotten in our. best wishes and our most earnest pray CTS.

 The cause of evangelical piety in this state is manifestly on the advance. The Christian bosom is expanding with holy bencvolence,& the eye of Christian compassionis is opening on the destitute at home and abroad. Whilst those who have forsaken the good old way of puritan godliness and truth, find themselves in crooked paths and likely to be led forth with the workers ofiniquity. G. a.

 NORTH CONSOLATION OF LITCHFIELD

 COUNTY.

 7othe Editor of the Connecticut O6seruer.

 DEAR SIR,-I have just returned from the annual meeting of the North Association of Litchfeld County. Never did attend 80 interesting a meeting of this association be- fore... The usual complaint of prevailing coldness and indifference on the subject of re- ligion, among our congregations, not a single brother present had occasion to make. A spirit of revival, which may be defined to be an unusual spirit of piety and brotherly love, appeared to animate every heart present, and was manifest in all the prayers and dellbera- tions of the body. The following is an extract from their report on the state of reli- zion.

 "The Association embraces within its lim- its 19 churches, 1S of which have at present settled pastors. Since the last annual report one pastor has been removed by death, one dismissed from his pastoral charge, and two settled. The additions to our respective churches during the year past, amount in all, tits estimated, from seventy-fiye to one hun dred.

 "The present state of things among us, in a moral and religious respect, is interesting and animating to the heart that loves the cause of Zion. The shower of divine grace, which has been poured out on the region north of us, has extended also to us, and several of our churches have already shared largely in its refreshing influence. In Salisbury, Sharon North Canaan, South Canaan, and Norfolk, there has been for about two months past, that degree of religious excitement which is usually denominated a revival;" and in each of the places the work of grace appears to be ILl d UTURi cSSlNC StAICs ! HC CuubGHCS VI VvUn. sted, New Hartford, Goshen, North Cornwall and Kent,where a few weeks since no unus,,- al attention to religion existed, are now en- toying incipient revivals of very encouraging promise. The churches of Winchester, Tor ringford, Ellsworth, South Cornwall, and Warren, the Spirit of God is likewise awak- ening from their moral apathy, imparting to them an unsual spirit of prayer and brotherly love, and affording them the anin1ating pros. pect of an approaching revival. The church in Colebrook has been in this state of religious excitement for several months past. It may he asserted without exaggeration, that in ev- cry church and congregation within our linn- its-with perhaps single exception-there is at present an unusually interesting state of re- Iigious feeling. At Canton, where revival has recently commenced, the Lord is now pouring out his Spirit in copious effusions. The place itself appears to be rendered very solemn by the special presence of the AL mighty.

 The late resignation in the British Cabinet have called into action the talents of the wits of London, who are by no means sparing of their shafts. One of the best articles we have seen, is the annexed from the London Morning Chronicle, which will be enjoyed by our readers, particularly those who are acquainted with the characters of the satiris-

The late resignation in the British Cabinet have called into action the talents of the wits of London, who are by no means sparing of their shafts. One of the hest articles we have seen, is the annexed from the London Morning Chronicle, which will be enjoyed by our readers, particularly those who are acquainted with the characters of the satiris- ed individuals.

 From the London Morning Chronice]

 Dreadful Suicide-Coroner's lnguest.-An inquest was held last week on the bodies of six unhappy Gentlemen, whose rash acts had been the subject of wonder and surprise for days past. The jury assembled at the sign of Ihe Hand tn Pocket, in Westminster, and Mir. J. Bull presided as Coroner. The bad odour from the subjects was intollerable, and notwithstanding the afflicting nature oi the spectacle, more haDdkerchiefs were ap- piled to the nose than to the eyes.

 The first body viewed by the Jury was that of Lord Eldon. It bore striking marks of decay. and the surprise is that nature had not dismissed to it's home, long before the fa- tai deed of violence was committed. Moth ing remained of the heart but mere sack, or bag of leather, resembling purse; the liver was of singular yhiteness the head discos- ed indications of having been long past ser vice, but the hands seemed to have retained their faculty of fgrasping in extraordinary per

It is plain that the deceased destroyed himself, under the dcllsion that he was about to do wrong to others; and as his purpose was criminal, it should effect the act; you will therefore, do well :n returning verdict of felo de SC, and the remains shall he deposited with every circumstance of fignominy in the cross road"

 MT. H.: Gin great distress)" For Heavens sake Gentlemen, take care that there is no turnpike near the cross road. for the cry of two pence in the neighborhood would raise Fmy Lord from the grave"

 ] The next body viewed was that of MT. Peel. His head looked as if it had taken fire. The person formerly 80 fair was covered with lvid marks of modification. It was given in evidence that the defunct had an insuppor- table aversion to MT. Canning as Premier, as he suspected him of an intention to smug- gle the Pope into the country. On the day of the rash act he had been reading The Up l holsterer, and the following parts were blis- tered with tears, and underlined in pencil "Mr. Razor: I say Mr. Qnidnunc, can't sleep in my bed for thinking of the Protes- tants if the Papists should get the better"

 Quidnunc; I'll tell your--the geographer of our coffee-house was saying the other day. that there is huge tract of land about the pole. Note. in the unhappy gentleman's hand writing. We have sent Perry to find it out] where the Protestsnts may return, and that the Papist will never be able to beat them out, if the Northern powers hold together, and the Grand Turk makes diversion in their favor."

 "Razon: That makes me easy. I'm glad the Protestantswi know where to go if the Papist should get the better."

 The jury in order to prevent the forfeiture of the defunct's high character, were charita- ply induced to return verdict of Insanity. | The Duke of Wellington was next viewed. The hero who had triumphed in so many pitched battles. had perished, it appeared, by breaking his own head just by way of expe- (riment of his powers. Witnesses were called, who proved that his Grace had discovered great irritability on the appointment of MT. Canning, ana declared that he saw no reason why he should be content with being C@ssf alone, and that he would be also Cesar and the First Lord ofthe Treasury, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Duchy of Lancaster, Lord High Chancellor of England, apd his vice too, Master of the Rolls and ofthe Horse, and Master Extraordinary in the Chancery, aut nullus. On receiving Mr. Canning notes, and finding that it was not probahe that he could occupy all these stations, 40 resolved on falling, not like Roman, on bis sword but on his head. The melancholy catastrophe is known to all. An attempt was made to show that this brave soldier was terribly afraid ofthe Pope, and disordered in intellect by that ap- prehensiOn, n,-but the jury treated 1t with con- tempt and returned verdict of telo de SC. | The carcasses of Lords Westmoreland, Bathurst, and Melville. were then viewed. Land

 in fits of temporary insanity, hut were remnd-

 The annexed pOetical squib owes it's origin to Lord Melville, who said " For himselfhe declared distinctly, and on his honor. that from the hour of Lord LiverpooPs illness down to the hour of his resignation, he had not the slightest communication of any kind or description, with any of his colleagues re- garding the formation of new Administra- tion, and that there was of course no concert or conspiracy to resign.

 "When they do agree, their unanimity is wonderful" q SheridGn's Oritic."

 EXTRAORDINARY CONFLICT.

 Amongst other publications illustrative of country, asd the fearful chances of, our bor- der warfare, are articles published in the Ken lucky Gazette, etitled notes on Kentucky They are brief but interesting skethes giving the vivid details of scenes calculated to im- to which the early settlers of that, and other western states were exposed. The following are the details of one of the most extraordin- ary of these incidents :l-Alb. Argus.

 In the year f79l, Capt. William Hubbell, who had recently removed to Kentucky from Vermont, with his family, and after having fixed his family in the neighbourhood of Frankfort, then a frontier settlement, had re- turned to the eastward on business and was second time on his way to Kentucky; by the Ohio River. On the Monongahela, one of the branches Ofthe Ohio, he procured fiat boat, and embarked with Mir. Daniel Light, Mir. William Plascut, and his family consist ing of his wife and eight children destined for Limestone, (Kentucky.) On their progress down the river Ohio, ,and soon after passing Pittsburgh, they saw evident traces of Indian foes along the banks and there was evident reason that boat which they overlook, and which, through carelessness, was suffered to run aground on an island, had become prey to these merciless savages. Though Captain Hubbell and his party stopped for some time in the low part of the river, it did not arrlve, and it has never been by them heard of since. Before they reached the Mouth the Great Kenhawa they had by several successive ad- ditions, increased their number to twenty, consisting of men, women, & 8 children. The men, besides those already named, were John Stoner, an Irishman and Dutchman, (WhOse names are mot .recOlleCted) Messrs. Ray & Tucker and MT. Fitzpatrick, who had two daughters also on board. Informa- tion received at GaIliopolis confirmed the ex- pectatiOn, which appearances had previously raised, of serious conflict with large body of Indians; and, as Capt. Hubbell had been regularly appointed commander of the boat. every possible preparation for formidable and successful resistance to any expected attack was promptly made. The nine men were divided into three watch es for the night, which were alternately to continue awake and be on the look out for 2 hours at time.-The arms on board which consisted principally of old muskets much out of order, were collected, loaded and put in the best possible condition for service. At about sunset on the 2Sd of March l79l, this party overlook fleet of six boats in compa- ny, and intended to have continued with them, but as their passengers seemed more disposed to dancing than fighting, and soon after dark, notwithstanding the remonstranccs of Capt. Hubbell, they commenced fddling, and dancing and drinking, instead of prepar- ing their arms and taking the rest preparato- ry to battle-it was deemed more hazardous to be in such company than to be without them.-It was therefore determined, to pro- ceed rapidly forward by aid of the oars, and to leave those thoughtless fellows behind.- One of the boats, however, belonging to the fleet, commanded by Captain Greenhouse, pursued the same plan for short time, but at length all the crew fell asleep, and the boat ceased to be propelled by oars fell behind, whilst Capt. Hubbell and his party glided forward steadily alone. Early in the night a canoe was dimly seen floating bown the river

 in which it was supposed there were Indians accommodating and other indications of the neighbourhood and hostile intentions of a formidable and savage party of Indians mo- ticed.

 It was now agreed, that should an attack, as was probable,he deferred till morning, every man should be up before the dawn of day. in order to make as great a show as possible, of numbers and of strength and. that whenev- CT an action should take place, the women and children should lie down on the cabin floor, and be protected as we'll as they could, by trunks and other baggage placed around them. In this perilous situation they contin- ued during the night, and the captain, who had not slept more than an hour since he lett

 Pittsburgh, was too deeply impressed with the eminent danger which surrounded them to obtain rest at that time.

 Just as day light began to appear in the east and before the men were up and at their posts agreeably to arrangement, voice at some distance below them in plaintive tone. re. peatedly solicited them to come on shore, as theresMere some white men who wished te obtain U passage in their boat. This the cap tain very naturally and correctly concluded te | be an Indian artiRce, and its only effect wa: | to rouse the men and place every one on hi

coming in and observing the leaf, the text, and her husbands name, added her own shortly after his sister entering observed it, 'and:' :'ad- ded her name and the result was the three became nious, and that house became house of prayer.

 After these and several interesting ac- counts, some hundreds Ofthe children of God sat down together about the sacramental board, and commemOrated that wonderful d. tenement which procured them all their priv iliges and comforts, and laid the foundation for all these triumphs of divine truthSwhch are making glad the hearts of men and an gels.

 In the evening a powerful appeal was made by the Reverend Mir. Hewitt, expos ing the wide spread and horrible evils of intemperanee, and calling upon the minis ters of the most high God, by all their sO- lemn obligations and awful responsibilities to throw themselves in between the living and the dead.

 After which the Association passed u- nanimous resolve approving the object and principles of the" American Society for the promotion of Temperance"

 On Thursday forenoon, a sermon was preached and prayer-meetings were held of an hour each On the mornings of Wednesday and Thursday. All the meetings were well attended and discovered deep and solemn interest, and we cannot but hope blessing is left for the people and pastor of the place, who will not we trustb he soon forgotten in our. best wishes and our most earnest pray CTS.

 The cause of evangelical piety in this state is manifestly on the advance. The Christian bosom is expanding with holy bencvolence,& the eye of Christian compassionis is opening on the destitute at home and abroad. Whilst those who have forsaken the good old way of puritan godliness and truth, find themselves in crooked paths and likely to be led forth with the workers ofiniquity. G. a.

 NORTH CONSOLATION OF LITCHFIELD

 COUNTY.

 7othe Editor of the Connecticut O6seruer.

 DEAR SIR,-I have just returned from the annual meeting of the North Association of Litchfeld County. Never did attend 80 interesting a meeting of this association be- fore... The usual complaint of prevailing coldness and indifference on the subject of re- ligion, among our congregations, not a single brother present had occasion to make. A spirit of revival, which may be defined to be an unusual spirit of piety and brotherly love, appeared to animate every heart present, and was manifest in all the prayers and dellbera- tions of the body. The following is an extract from their report on the state of reli- zion.

 "The Association embraces within its lim- its 19 churches, 1S of which have at present settled pastors. Since the last annual report one pastor has been removed by death, one dismissed from his pastoral charge, and two settled. The additions to our respective churches during the year past, amount in all, tits estimated, from seventy-fiye to one hun dred.

 "The present state of things among us, in a moral and religious respect, is interesting and animating to the heart that loves the cause of Zion. The shower of divine grace, which has been poured out on the region north of us, has extended also to us, and several of our churches have already shared largely in its refreshing influence. In Salisbury, Sharon North Canaan, South Canaan, and Norfolk, there has been for about two months past, that degree of religious excitement which is usually denominated a revival;" and in each of the places the work of grace appears to be ILl d UTURi cSSlNC StAICs ! HC CuubGHCS VI VvUn. sted, New Hartford, Goshen, North Cornwall and Kent,where a few weeks since no unus,,- al attention to religion existed, are now en- toying incipient revivals of very encouraging promise. The churches of Winchester, Tor ringford, Ellsworth, South Cornwall, and Warren, the Spirit of God is likewise awak- ening from their moral apathy, imparting to them an unsual spirit of prayer and brotherly love, and affording them the anin1ating pros. pect of an approaching revival. The church in Colebrook has been in this state of religious excitement for several months past. It may he asserted without exaggeration, that in ev- cry church and congregation within our linn- its-with perhaps single exception-there is at present an unusually interesting state of re- Iigious feeling. At Canton, where revival has recently commenced, the Lord is now pouring out his Spirit in copious effusions. The place itself appears to be rendered very solemn by the special presence of the AL mighty.

The late resignation in the British Cabinet have called into action the talents of the wits of London, who are by no means sparing of their shafts. One of the hest articles we have seen, is the annexed from the London Morning Chronicle, which will be enjoyed by our readers, particularly those who are acquainted with the characters of the satiris- ed individuals.

 From the London Morning Chronice]

 Dreadful Suicide-Coroner's lnguest.-An inquest was held last week on the bodies of six unhappy Gentlemen, whose rash acts had been the subject of wonder and surprise for days past. The jury assembled at the sign of Ihe Hand tn Pocket, in Westminster, and Mir. J. Bull presided as Coroner. The bad odour from the subjects was intollerable, and notwithstanding the afflicting nature oi the spectacle, more haDdkerchiefs were ap- piled to the nose than to the eyes.

 The first body viewed by the Jury was that of Lord Eldon. It bore striking marks of decay. and the surprise is that nature had not dismissed to it's home, long before the fa- tai deed of violence was committed. Moth ing remained of the heart but mere sack, or bag of leather, resembling purse; the liver was of singular yhiteness the head discos- ed indications of having been long past ser vice, but the hands seemed to have retained their faculty of fgrasping in extraordinary per
